history.content: You only need to take 61A/61B/70 in order to declare, which you should definitely do before junior fall semester. There is no strict requirement to take your other lower division requirements by a certain time (other than by the time you graduate), although it is in your best interest to finish them sooner as many upper divisions EE/CS classes have them as prereqs.

You only need to take 61A/61B/70 in order to declare, which you should definitely do before junior fall semester. There is no strict requirement to take your other lower division requirements by a certain time, although it is in your best interest to finish them sooner as many upper divisions EE/CS classes have them as prereqs.

You really should take courses in the recommended pattern. It's in your interest. 16ab are designed to be taken before 70. What is causing the pressure on your schedule that is blocking the completion of the lower div? 

16B is core to ML, Data Science (mathy side PCA, etc), analog circuits, SP, AI, robotics, etc. 

61C is core to software, digital circuits, etc. 

If both of these are getting pushed, you're essentially blocking the vast majority of dept courses conceptually. Even 170 does the fft which builds on 16b. 

Are you a double major with something else very different?

children.subject:
If you are interested in Data Science, then 16B is absolutely core for you. 

Trust me. If your interest in CS is primarily on the machine learning side, then you really want to take EE16B and do well in it. And to do so sooner rather than later. (EE16AB will help you in DS100.) 

Relevant announcements will probably happen early next term.

Hi, Professor Sahai,

Thank you for the response! I was the OP of this post and @5769 (https://piazza.com/class/hyq0br1u3kx7dg?cid=5769). This helps explain my situation/classes/background better, and my current dilemma. The details are enclosed in the post.

Basically, I want to pursue a minor in Data Science and major in CS, while also successfully declaring CS as someone with no previous computer science, linear algebra, statistics, or physics experience. I understand the courses were designed to not require extensive experience in their respective subject categories, but (just taking Data 8 and EE16A this semester) was fairly challenging - primarily due to EE16A. Though I did end up doing fine in both courses, if I took EE16A with 61A, I know would've either done poorly in 61A (which I couldn't have afforded) or EE16A (hurting my GPA), or even both. 

Though I would ideally take EE16B and CS61A (if my grade in 61A was not as much a stress factor), it was that insight that  leans me towards the decision of dropping EE16B in my schedule projected for next semester - to ensure I successfully digest the content in CS61A, and do well in the course, and then digest the content of 16B when I take it later (under less stressful, GPA-Demanding circumstances).

I'm still debating, and would still like to hear opinions before I finalize my decision. I have already spoke to Professor Alon in Office Hours (who originally leaned me towards taking EE16B) but now I am hesitant as I realize the reality of my schedule next semester, and the demand of declaring CS.

Hi there, 

I think that's fine, but want to make sure you've sketched out your last two years, assuming you don't plan to do any summer school. Here's a possible idea:

JR Fall: EE 16B  & EECS UD #1 & internship recruiting 

JR Spring: CS 61C & EECS UD #2

SR Fall: EECS UD #3, EECS US #4 & UD Tech Elective #1 & recruiting/applying to grad school 

SR Spring: EECS UD #5 & UD Tech Elective #2

Plus any remaining general education courses, planning for an alternate major (should you not make the GPA), and all data science minor courses. Only one UD course can overlap between your major and minor.

Hi, this is the OP. Thank you so much! I was really stressed out, so this helps a lot. A few questions:

Right now for the Data Minor Upper Division Requirements it has:

  • one semester of Data 100 (COMPSCI/STAT C100) and a selection of three or four additional courses.

Assuming I overlap one course and there are three necessary, this still means I would need to fit two more DATA Upper Divs in my junior and senior years, correct? Do you recommend I plan to take these over summer classes, or fit them in the schedule you provided?

Also, wouldn't it be more advantageous to take 61C earlier, from a recruiting point of view? (i.e. Swap positions of EE16B and 61C) Just wanted to know what your motivation was for putting 61C and EE16B in those positions. 

Thanks again!

Hi there, 

From what you included, it sounds like the Data Science minor would be an additional 3-4 upper division courses on top of what I listed. I am hesitant for you to add them to the existing schedule, as 3-4 techs per semester can be a lot. I would look into EE 16B or CS 61C over summer. 

Totally up to you which you take first. I listed EE 16B in Fall only to try to limit the amount of time in-between 16a and 16b. It's suggested that students take them consecutively.

Freshman CS/Data Course Planning Help? Don't know what to do...

Hi all,

I'm currently a freshman in intended CS (L&S) that has taken EE16A, Data 8, and two breadths. I am interested in majoring in CS and potentially minoring in Data Science and I needed some course advice.

For next semester, I am currently enrolled in CS61A, EE16B, and two breadth and some random extra 1-2 units. However, I have no CS experience (but Data 8) and would really like to declare CS, so I was considering dropping EE16B to ensure I do well in 61A. This year was fairly challenging for me and I was only in Data 8 (Didn't have stats experience, not a "difficult" class per-se from popular opinion and I would agree) and EE16A (very time-consuming, no physics/linear algebra experience, couldn't pick up concepts quickly). Plus, I don't really need to take 16B in my first two years (correct?) so I could just take it as a senior.

But I was just worried if I was making the right decision. If I drop 16B, then I keep 61A and just two breadths (Versus dropping a breadth and keeping CS61A, EE16B, and the other breadth). Would dropping EE16B (and taking it sometime senior year) put me behind on my CS Major+Data Minor track? I am planning on taking 61B and DS100 in my sophomore Fall, and then just CS70 and some breadths in the sophomore spring. Then I would declare and could take 61C, EE16B and my Data-Minor/CS-Major upper Divs in my junior-senior years..?

All thoughts and advice are HIGHLY appreciated! Currently stumped and need help....

history.content:
Hi, all, I am currently a freshman. 

https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/degree-reqs-lowerdiv

According to this website, 

  • Math 1A (Calculus I) *can be satisfied with at least a “3” on the AP AB or BC Calculus exam, at least a “5” on the IB Math Higher Level, or at least a "B" on A-Level Math

  • Math 1B (Calculus II) *can be satisfied with a “5” on the AP BC Calculus exam or at least a "B" on A-Level Further Math

  • EE 16A (Designing Information Devices and Systems I) or Math 54 (Linear Algebra and Differential Equations)

  • EE 16B (Designing Information Devices and Systems II)

  • CS 61A (Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs)

  • CS 61B/BL (Data Structures)

  • CS 61C (Machine Structures)

  • CS 70 (Discrete Mathematics and Probability Theory) *Math 55 is accepted for math/cs double-majors, but CS 70 is recommended. Math grade will be used in the GPA calculation. Students need to be declared in math first.

Are all lower division requirements. Does this mean that I have to take all of these courses by junior fall? At my current plan, I will only have 1A/B, 61A, 61B, CS70, EE16A by junior year fall (not EE16B and CS61C). Is this enough to declare by junior year? 

Thanks!
history.subject: Help: Lower Division Requirements CS?
